Using SSH with GitHub

Short tutorial about setting up SSH keys for GitHub.

Published on September 13, 2021 by Shannon Tass

ssh git github

2 min READ

This post is adapted from the GitHub documentation page Connecting to GitHub with SSH.

You can use the SSH protocol by setting up SSH keys to connect with GitHub without needing to supply your username and access token. SSH stands for Secure Shell and it protocol for operating network services securely over an unsecured network. You can read more about SSH here.

Check for existing SSH keys

  1. Open the terminal (Mac) or Git Bash (Windows)
  2. Enter ls -la ~/.ssh

  3. Check the directory listing to see if you have a public SSH key, usually:

    • id_rsa.pub
    • id_ecdsa.pub
    • id_ed25519.pub
  4. If you receive an error that ~/.ssh doesn‚Äôt exist, then you don‚Äôt have ssh keys

Generating New SSH Keys

(If you already have SSH keys, skip to the next section.)

Below are instructions for generating SSH keys. When doing this, you have the choice of an algorithm to use (with the -t option) and the key size (with the -b option). You can read more about SSH keys and the different algorithm/key size options here. The instructions below use the rsa algorithm with a 4096 bit key size.

  1. Open the terminal (Mac) or Git Bash (Windows)
  2. In the terminal type
    ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -C "your_github_email@email.com"
    (be sure to use your actual GitHub email address)
  3. When you are prompted to ‚ÄúEnter a file in which to save the key‚Äù, just press enter to accept the default location
  4. Add a passphrase for extra security or press enter for no passphrase

Adding SSH Keys to your GitHub Account

  1. Copy the SSH public key to the clipboard.
    cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub will show you the public key and you can copy it.
  2. Go to GitHub. In the upper-right corner, click on your profile photo, then click Settings.
  3. In the user settings sidebar, click SSH and GPG keys
  4. Click New SSH key
  5. In the ‚ÄúTitle‚Äù field, add a label for your key. For example ‚ÄúPersonal MacBook Air‚Äù
  6. Paste your key into the ‚ÄúKey‚Äù field.
  7. Click Add SSH key.

Using SSH Key

In GitHub, when cloning repositories, or setting up the remote repository, use SSH instead of HTTP:
